page.title: Timeline of the 2011 Egyptian revolution under Supreme Council of the Armed Forces

rev.diff:
Line 115: Line 115:
[[File:Tahrir Square on July 08 2011.jpg|thumb|Hundreds of thousands<ref name="Ahram08">{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/15899/Egypt/Politics-/Hundreds-of-thousands-revitalise-Egypts-revolution.aspx |title=Hundreds of thousands revitalise Egypt's revolution on Determination Friday - Politics - Egypt - Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref> of people protesting in Tahrir Square on 8 July 2011]]
[[File:Tahrir Square on July 08 2011.jpg|thumb|Hundreds of thousands<ref name="Ahram08">{{cite web|url=http://english.ahram.org.eg/NewsContent/1/64/15899/Egypt/Politics-/Hundreds-of-thousands-revitalise-Egypts-revolution.aspx |title=Hundreds of thousands revitalise Egypt's revolution on Determination Friday - Politics - Egypt - Ahram Online |publisher=English.ahram.org.eg |date= |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref> of people protesting in Tahrir Square on 8 July 2011]]
â
A Facebook page titled "The Second Egyptian Revolution of Rage" reads: "Seeing that the situation, under the leadership of the Supreme Council of the Armed Forces, is only going from bad to worse, and since the council has proven from day one that public pressure is the most effective policy for achieving the demands of the legitimate revolution, we have decided to take to the streets and squares [once again] and demonstrate throughout Egypt until our demands are met..."<ref name="memri1">{{cite news|title=Disappointed with Revolution's Gains, Egyptians Renew Protests|url=http://www.memri.org/report/en/0/0/0/0/0/0/5429.htm|accessdate=5 July 2011|newspaper=http://www.memri.org/|date=3 July 2011}}</ref> On the 1st July, tens of thousands of protesters gathered in Suez, Alexandria and Tahrir Square in Cairo, to voice frustrations with the ruling Supreme Council of the Armed Forces for what they perceived to be the slow pace of change, five months after Mubarak's ousting<ref>{{cite web|url=http://channel6newsonline.com/2011/07/thousands-of-egyptians-protest-against-police-brutality/ |title=Channel 6 News Â» Thousands of Egyptians protest against police brutality |publisher=Channel6newsonline.com |date= |accessdate=2011-07-02}}</ref> calling it the '''"Friday of Retribution"'''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailynewsegypt.com/egypt/thousands-demonstrate-on-friday-of-retribution.html |title=Thousands demonstrate on 'Friday of Retribution' |publisher=Thedailynewsegypt.com |date= |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref>.
+
A Facebook page titled "The Second Egyptian Revolution of Rage" reads: "Seeing that the situation, under the leadership of the [[Supreme Council of the Armed Forces]], is only going from bad to worse, and since the council has proven from day one that public pressure is the most effective policy for achieving the demands of the legitimate revolution, we have decided to take to the streets and squares [once again] and demonstrate throughout Egypt until our demands are met..."<ref name="memri1">{{cite news|title=Disappointed with Revolution's Gains, Egyptians Renew Protests|url=http://www.memri.org/report/en/0/0/0/0/0/0/5429.htm|accessdate=5 July 2011|newspaper=http://www.memri.org/|date=3 July 2011}}</ref> On the 1st July, tens of thousands of protesters gathered in Suez, Alexandria and Tahrir Square in Cairo, to voice frustrations with the ruling Supreme Council of the Armed Forces for what they perceived to be the slow pace of change, five months after Mubarak's ousting<ref>{{cite web|url=http://channel6newsonline.com/2011/07/thousands-of-egyptians-protest-against-police-brutality/ |title=Channel 6 News Â» Thousands of Egyptians protest against police brutality |publisher=Channel6newsonline.com |date= |accessdate=2011-07-02}}</ref> calling it the '''"Friday of Retribution"'''<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailynewsegypt.com/egypt/thousands-demonstrate-on-friday-of-retribution.html |title=Thousands demonstrate on 'Friday of Retribution' |publisher=Thedailynewsegypt.com |date= |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref>.
â
On 4 July 2011, an explosion at the pipeline near [[Nagah]] in the Sinai Peninsula haltied natural gas supplies to Israel and Jordan.<ref name=aljazeera040711/> An official said that armed men with machine guns forced guards at the station to leave before planting explosive charge there.<ref name=aljazeera040711/> This is the third attack on Egyptian gas pipelines since an uprising overthrew Hosni Mubarak.<ref name=aljazeera040711/> There was also a failed attempt to attack the pipeline in March.<ref name=aljazeera040711>{{cite news | agency = [[Al Jazeera]]| url= http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/07/2011740176861868.html | title = Blast hits Egyptian gas pipeline | date = 2011-07-04 | accessdate=2011-07-04}}</ref>
+
On 4 July 2011, an explosion at the [[Arab Gas Pipeline|pipeline]] near [[Nagah]] in the [[Sinai Peninsula]] haltied natural gas supplies to Israel and Jordan.<ref name=aljazeera040711/> An official said that armed men with machine guns forced guards at the station to leave before planting explosive charge there.<ref name=aljazeera040711/> This is the third attack on Egyptian gas pipelines since an uprising overthrew Hosni Mubarak.<ref name=aljazeera040711/> There was also a failed attempt to attack the pipeline in March.<ref name=aljazeera040711>{{cite news | agency = [[Al Jazeera]]| url= http://english.aljazeera.net/news/middleeast/2011/07/2011740176861868.html | title = Blast hits Egyptian gas pipeline | date = 2011-07-04 | accessdate=2011-07-04}}</ref>
â
On the 8th July, hundreds of of thousands<ref name="Ahram08"/> of protesters gathered in Suez, Alexandria and Tahrir Square in Cairo, to demand immediate reforms and swifter prosecution of former officials from the toppled government of Hosni Mubarak<ref name="aljazeera1">{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/middleeast/2011/07/20117810134178303.html |title=New protests rage across Egypt - Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref> calling it the '''"Friday of Determination"'''<ref name="Ahram08"/>. Most of Egypt's political parties and coalitions, including the Muslim Brotherhood, supported widespread calls for the protest to be staged across Egypt.<ref name="aljazeera1"/> The main demand of these groups is to combine efforts toward achieving the goals of the revolution, including: banning the trail of civilians by military courts; raising the minimum wage; bringing Mubarak, his sons, and the senior officials of his regime to justice; banning former National Democratic Party (NDP) members from political activity for five years; releasing all political prisoners; purging the police, the legal system, the media, the universities and the banks of members of the former regime; electing new municipal councils and stopping the exportation of natural gas to Israel.<ref name="memri1"/>
+
On the 8th July, hundreds of of thousands<ref name="Ahram08"/> of protesters gathered in [[Suez]], [[Alexandria]] and [[Tahrir Square]] in [[Cairo]] demanding immediate reforms and swifter [[Trials and judicial hearings following the 2011 Egyptian revolution|prosecution of former officials]] from the toppled government of [[Hosni Mubarak]]<ref name="aljazeera1">{{cite web|url=http://english.aljazeera.net/video/middleeast/2011/07/20117810134178303.html |title=New protests rage across Egypt - Middle East |publisher=Al Jazeera English |date= |accessdate=2011-07-10}}</ref> calling it the '''"Friday of Determination"'''<ref name="Ahram08"/>. Most of Egypt's political parties and coalitions, including the [[Muslim Brotherhood]], supported widespread calls for the protest to be staged across Egypt.<ref name="aljazeera1"/> The main demand of these groups is to combine efforts toward achieving the goals of the revolution, including: [[Human rights in Egypt under the Supreme Council of the Armed Forces|banning the trail of civilians by military courts]]; raising the minimum wage; bringing Mubarak, his sons, and the senior officials of his regime to justice; banning former National Democratic Party (NDP) members from political activity for five years; releasing all political prisoners; purging the police, the legal system, the media, the universities and the banks of members of the former regime; electing new municipal councils and stopping the exportation of natural gas to Israel.<ref name="memri1"/>
